column2: catz4u07, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have degeneratve disc disease, stenosis, arthritis and fibromyalgia. Had cervical laminectomy in 2004. Can't use Oxycontin, due to severe itching, vicodin is okay but doesn't help the pain much and percocets make me sweat like I'm in the 7th circle of hell, even though they help with pain taken in conjunction with 600 mg ibuprofen.  20 mg liquid morphene is perfect for high pain days..no side effects, no tiredness, just no pain, but lots of luck getting it..my pain doc that I went to gave me 20 mg morphene pills sustained release and they ARE NOT the same..gave me stomach cramps, destroyed my appetite and didn't do crap for pain. I have had no trouble over 8 years with getting addicted to any pain meds.  If you are careful and do not take more than what you need and even take less on days you can get by with less, you will have no problem.  If you are popping them just because you have them whether you need them or not..you will develop a tolerance faster and also will become addicted. I need to go back to my doctor and find something for bad pain days that works without making me sweat to death...if it weren't for the sweating, these would be fine.  For those of you with fibromyalgia and other inflammatory issues...TART Cherry juice..in the refrigerator section at your grocery store.  About 17 dollars for a bottle, but it works and lasts for quite a while..also pineapple contains anti-inflammatory qualities...taking the Tart Cherry Juice got me off of the anti-depressant med for fibro pain~I got relief within several days of taking it. The less meds you can get by with..the better for you and your health!

column2: Spartan, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am an acute migraine sufferer for more than 20 years, ever since a combat related injury occured. Orginally I used the Percocet as a break through drug for migraines lasting more than 2 days and  when max doses of other drugs are not working. This drug has helped very well. But now,instead of taking this when the pain meds I have do not help, I take Percocet in the morning with Tylenol 3 and once in the evening with Tylenol 3. Doing this allows me to be pain free and be proactive and stave off the pain ahead of time. Because of this, I went from having to go to the emergency room 1 to 3 times per month when the regular meds did not work so they can give me a shot of Dilaudid, to having to get a shot of Dilaudid only 2 times this whole year. It works and my quality of life has improved 75% or more. I also use p/t, chiropractic care and accupunture as well as exercise to deal with muscle aches and stiffness. Migraines are only a part of the issue, I also suffer acute spinal pain from combat injuries and nerve damage to right side. So, this drug has helped 100 fold for me.

column2: Alan, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Percocet 10 is prescribed for me for relief of pain in the hip, wrist, back and shin. I have to say, it has no effect on my pain whatsoever. I don't ken the pain relief aspect of this medication.It does provide a mild plesant sensation or "euphoria" when it first takes effect and so I continue to use it, though "euphoria" grossly overstates the effect. The effect then wears off in short order, perhaps two hours. It is very like a shot of whisky in that way, though I never drink alcohol. I have no sensation of addiction, beyond the addiction that would accompany any other plesant habit. Certainly, nothing like alcohol or tobbacco. When it is available, I take recourse in it. When it isn't, I don't. It is generally too difficult to obtain and inures too easily for it to ever be a problem at the level of alcohol.

column2: fyresq, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am a retired Firefighter/Paramedic, with numerous, chronic musculo-skeletal pain sites due to job related trauma(s)  The most debilitating is a C5-6 & C6-7 herniation of the discs.  I had C4-5 fused in 1998, but degeneration continued, causing shoulder and arm pain.  I also have 2 torn rotator cuffs(since 2007), which is much more severe as the pain goes.  I am inoperable, due to a series of strokes(coumadin, plavix), and my MD would rather prescribe vicodin and soma(both generic) than risk hemhorrage.  I take 4-7.5/d of each, and often fewer, depending on pain level.  If I miss a dosage, I do go into pre-withdrawal, sweats, irritability, etc.  However, I have found this drug to be effective in pain mgmt.  I NEVER experience a "high", just relief.  Constipation is cured with a bowl of Grape Nuts and a fiber diet.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: It stays in your system about 72 hours. However, morphine drug tests are less sensitive to oxycodone. They will only pick up high doses. There is a specific urine test for oxycodone, hydrocodone which usually is not included on a basic 7panel drug test. It is usually included on a 15 panel or healthcare prof drug panel. But regardless, 72 hours is the most.

column2: YorkieMum, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've had Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction for almost thirty years. I was one of the first patients diagnosed at Cedar Sinai.  I underwent a sphincterplasty, but the common duct continued to spasm.  Other than Demerol and Phenergan IM in a hospital, Percocet is the only drug that can relieve the incredible pain that comes with these episodes.  Don't take more than you absolutely need just because you have it on hand. Make sure that you get the brand name and not a generic.  They are by no means the same.  I split the tablets and take 1/4 every half hour until I have a reasonable reduction in pain.  I have been successful in avoiding addiction for thirty years and still been able to managethe high level of pain that comes with these episodes.

column2: RN1993, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Percocet for breakthrough pain in conjunction with Duragesic 100mcg/hr for more than 5yrs. These medications have made it possible for me to continue working as an RN in a long term care facility where I physically interact with my patients.  I have degenerative disc disease, fibromyalgia & 3 herniated disks. I need to take care of my disabled parents when I am not at work, so I have not been able to take time off for surgery & recovery. I say hooray for medications like this! As long as they are taken responsibly, as prescribed, the risk of addiction is minimal. People need to communicate with their physicians when their current pain medication is no longer effective so they can explore other pain control options before their pain gets out of control.  It is much easier to keep the pain under control than it is to let it run wild & then try to get it back under control. Your pysician will appreciate you taking a proactive roll in your own care.  If you are new to pain medications, you may want to try doing a "pain diary".  Keep track of what you're doing when your pain starts or increases, what makes it better (medication, rest, hot bath, heating pad, ice pack, etc) & what makes it worse (stress, too much activity, bending, lifting, cold weather, etc). Bring this diary with you to your doctor's appointment for your physician to review with you. You may also want to make out a list of things you want to talk to your doctor about before you go to your appointment so you don't forget what you want to speak to him/her about. Also bring a current list of your medications to every appointment. They appreciate this info as well.

column9: Ihave been taking Percocet 7.5/325 for almost a year now. I find that if I take 1/2 tablet then the other half about 30 minutes to an hour later and have eaten something it doesn't make me nauseated or groggy at all and I can take them at work and still function normally. I can repeat this dose every couple hours if needed. This works very well for me. I just don't take them right before going to bed because they make me relaxed but not sleepy. I only take them when the pain is really bad so I have absolutely no concerns about becoming addicted. I am fortunate to have a wonderful pain management doctor who knows  that I don't abuse any medications, and I also receive trigger point injections regularly.I have had chronic back and neck pain, headaches and sciatica for about 8 years. column9: This drug worked well for a little while but I do not recommend taking for long periods of time or when your pain may require surgery and long waits. I had a severe injury to my shoulder and took this for 1 1/2 years while I went through cort. shots and pt. When I quit taking the drug I had pretty significant withdrawal symptoms and serious depression. This takes 3 - 5 days to get out of your system. The other issue is the stereotype that you are a worthless junkie. You won't believe how many people will judge you for taking this, even if you are taking as directed. I would try something less addictive like Tylenol with Codeine. It is not nearly as addictive and I could have saved a lot of pain and misery.

column2: nambi, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My daughter was suffering with a lot of pain due to a staph infection. Not wanting to miss the last few days of work because she had taken a new job, she used percocet to relieve the pain.  My daughter passed away ten days after beginning the percocet.  It was a mistaken overdose with deadly results.  Do not take this drug!! It is dangerous and very addictive. My daughter would be alive today if a doctor had not prescribed this medicine. The average person thinks any drug a doctor prescribes is safe to take. Nothing could be further from the truth, one small mistake can take your life!

column2: lilbit, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
Carrie, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have considerable [if temporary] pain associated with facial plastic surgery. I can tolerate discomfort during the day, but by using Percocet at night, I had hoped for better sleep. Unfortunately, I have developed respiratory problems [2nd night onward] that supresses natural breathing to the point that I have had to sleep in a sitting position, supported by pillows. I have found that when I attempt to lie prone, I must make my thorax inflate deliberately. I do not know whether apnea syndrome would eventually cause spontaneous intake of air, or whether I might suffocate; I have been too concerned to relax my system in anticipation of survival. In any case, I am not much pleased by the apnea alternative, even though it would be transitory during the limited time use of Percocet.I mentioned my concern with my surgeon and he was perfectly relaxed about my continued use - no skin off his nose, I guess! I'd be better off with a glass of wine instead.

column2: e77toe77, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with 2 herniated and 2 bulging discs in my L region of my back.  Severe sciatic pain has hospitalized me twice in 6 yrs.  I have been on a consistent regime of 5mg percocet for the first 2-3 yrs taking 10-15mg per dose.  In the last few years, I have had to increase to 20-30mg per dose to achieve the same pain relief.  The most taken was 40mg at one time, however, not again that day.  I routinely get a new 100ct prescription at the 1st of the month and try to make it last the entire month, but some months are better than others. I am now on the 10mg tablets and make it pretty easy every month.  I wish there was a percocet prescription without the acetamenophen.   The only side affect that I have with the medication is that I will occasionally start sweating in my head and neck area.  It subsides in about 10-15 minutes, but is embarrasing if I am out on a job somewhere...it can get quite profuse.  Other than that, good to go.  It takes care of the pain and allows me to function at about 95% which is doable rather than at 0-30% with the pain.

You cannot become addicted by taking 1 a day.  Some days I do not need to take it at all.  But some mornings I can't even get out of bed to go to work. column2: kim129, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This is my opinion/answer to "Supershmoo," an 18yr old w/back pain or to any young person who is thinking about taking opiate-based drugs for long-term usage.YOU SHOULD NOT BE ON THIS DRUG FOR LONG-TERM USAGE! Percocet and/or Oxycontin should be the LAST DRUG you are given!I have sever rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis & ANV. I have been on a combo of Percocet & Oxycontin for about 5 years now for chronic pain. I have been on pain meds for about 15 years, and just like you, I was started on anti-inflammatories (non-opiates) first. As my arthritis got worse (over years), I was slowly given stronger and stronger pain meds, but wasn't given Percocet & Oxycontin until I was in so much pain I was (still am) using a walker and wheelchair. Your dr is correct by starting you with non-opiates. You are way too young and opiates are highly addictive. Also, keep in mind, the longer you take this type of drug, the less effective they become and the more you will need to ease your pain. If the anti-inflammatory doesn't work, your dr can try another one or combine it with a another non-opiate drug. You may also want to talk to your dr about a nerve block, which I hear works wonders for back pain.Let me tell you about this drug and other opiate based drugs. For short-term use, they are fine, but for long-time use at your age, they are not, especially Percocet and/or Oxycontin. The side-effects are horrible if you ever go through withdraw. I have gone through it, as I am sure other people writing a review have, and it isn't pleasant. I ran out of them before my dr & pharmacy would re-fill them and the I started to go through withdraw. I felt like I was having a heart-attack, sweating, twiching/jerking of my muscles, you can't sleep, can't eat, the list goes on and on.You are way too young for this drug or any opiate. What do you think they will be able to give you when you get older, if they give you on one of the strongest opiates first?

column9: I am 20 yr old female and i have extreme pain in my feet from bunions aas well as diabetic neuropathy. column2: flady, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I suffer from denegerate bone, joint,disc disease & Sickle Cell. The pain management team was called to work on my case due to post surgerical procedure the doctors could not manage the pain. My pain was unbearable I was given Morphine, then Dilaudid was tryed, but I was hysterical due to the pain. Once the Pain Management Team arrived my mother remembered that at age 12 I had a tonsilectomy & almost died from an overdose.The meds I was given were having no effect on me. It was discovered I was born with an extremely high tolerance to opium. It is very difficult to manage my pain, so I left pain management and chose a great primary care physician that changed my medication from the large amount of Percocet to Dilaudid 4 mg 3 times a day & I would love to say I am pain free, but I beleive he is on the right track. I was always concern the amount of Percocet I had to take just to get out of bed would eventually kill my kidneys or severly damage my liver. Hopefully, working with my Doctor given him feedback I write in my journal will assist him to get the correctt combination of meds & I can get my life back. My body is rapidly declining, but with God, Dr., PT and other life style changes I can return to work, utilize my degrees to regain a good quality of life. I would advise anyone that suffers from chronic severe pain to do research,so you can be an educated patient. In the long run you will feel alot better partcipating in your therapy and keep a journal of your activities and what triggers your pain & what gives you relief. A rule of thrumb honestly inform your physician everything interferring with your daily activities and things that help.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have a chronically pinched nerve from   broken ribs for over a year now. I cannot stress enough how debilitating the pain has become. I couldn't sit upright or even go to a resataurant or grocery store with out hollerin' before I started using this med.I can't sleep without itI'd be yelling in pain for hours.The weght of a bedsheet can set it off. Sometimes I can't even wear a shirt because the weight of the fabric can set it off. I couldn't be anywhere in public because of the involuntary pain induced vocalizations! (I scream when it give me a shot of hot knife in the chest)! I don't like taking it but have no choise and with out taking 3-4 5mg/day I have no life at all. I have had 4 apin blocks of diferent kinds...RF...Cryio...none of with helped for more than a few days.One precaution. Do NOT try to quit it cold turkey. I was having precipitous drops in blood pressure nearly passing out and found I had to taper down....2/day for a few days then 1/day for a week then 1/2 /day for a week then 1/4/day then 1/4 every other day for a week. Trouble is each time I waened myself off the pain block would fail and I had to get right back on.Do NOT exceed the prescribed dose as many have gotten adicted by doing so. I am mildly adicted so I need to taper down as above. I know a person that got really hooked and had to start buying them on the street and it nearly ruined the lives of both her and her family. She is a smart sweet girl, best friend w/my daughter (they are both serious athletes) who is against taking asprin and it ruined their friendship for a while until her 3rd detox. It can help you if used only as prescribed and ruin your life and those around you but if you are going for the buzz good luck you could get to the 50-75/day like my daughters friend. Just the tylenol alone will kill you by way of a rotted liver at those dosages.Use it if needed and be aware of what happens when you exceed prescribed. I hope this helps you.

column9: In 1997, I was a pedestrian struck by a motor vehicle traveling 55 mph. Amazingly, I suvived after coming out of a 3 week coma. Initially, I was given a Morphine button, injecting 4 mg every 8 minutes. I was also on Percocet every 4 hrs, 2 of the 5 mg tabs. After lots of physical therapy and rehabilitation, I learned to walk again and eventually went back home. I was given a prescription of Percocet 5/325. It worked ok for a while, but I was still in a lot of pain. Now,my doctor has me taking 10 mg every 4-6 hrs as needed. I get some relief from it, but I have found that there isn't any medication that TOTALLY relieves the pain. It is now 2010, and I still have to have total knee replacement sometime in the very near future. I also have a metal plate holding my pelvic bone together, and 2 metal plates in my left arm. Some days are better than others, I guess, it sort of depends on the situation and the weather. Lots of luck and prayers to everyone living with chronic pain.

The side effects of the medication slow my reflexes and can affect my memories and concentrationqjukee

column2: bulldog lover, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: To the person who used it for MRSA on 12/13 at 5pm--be careful.  My mom died of MRSA and one of the reasons they did not act fast enough is that the Motrin and the acetomeniphine in the Percocet she was taking masked her fever and they did not realize how bad the MRSA was until she was nearly dead.  By then it was too late.  I am sure you are aware of your condition and are already on the lookout, but to anyone who has an infection and is using it for pain, remember that a fever is the single biggest sign you have an infection or it is getting worse and percocet has other drugs in them that will reduce fevers.  Sounds pretty basic, but my mother's doctor did not seem to know this.

column9: I AM IN STAGE THREE WITH RSDS. THIS DRUG HAS MADE ME ABLE TO HAVE A LIFE. I AM 40 YEARS OLD I SUFFERED A DIRECT HIT FROM A GUN WHEN MY HOME WAS INVADED. THAT WAS OVER TEN YEARS AGO. column2: holycrossshadow, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have taken Percocet for a few years and it's the only drug that works effectively for me. Recently I was also prescribed Suboxone along with it and it makes the pain manageable and it also keeps you from needing to take higher doses. My pain management specialist in Carmel, IN is from a different country and has by far the best pain management facility in the state as far as I am concerned. When I first went to him I was on Fentynal patches, percocet, muscle relaxers and the list continued. He was able to change all of my medications around and add the suboxone and the combination of suboxone and percocet are all I need now and feel much better now than I had for the previous 8-10 yrs. I also prefer the Percocet because you don't get high off of them or make your sick or any side effect in my case and I can actually drive myself places and carry on a conversation instead of being all fuzzy and messed up on the patch and other shall we say coctail that I was on previously. It is a miracle drug in my opinion and now they are talking about taking all narcotics off of the market and have no idea what may happen then but foresee it being a huge problem for the entire country unless they are able to invent something suitable that can manage pain as well as this medication has been able to for many patients with chronic pain. Mine is chronic back pain and when a person is in a great deal of pain it also adds to a lot of depression and other mental and mood disorders. For anyone who does not have this type of condition they can't understand it but it's a miracle drug. Last of all I would like to state that I wish that Mr. President would keep his nose out of the health care business and stick to all of the other promises he made and not kept. We are to care for our elders, not take food out of their mouth, nor money out of their pockets to give to the poor. They are our responsibility! All of us and not the government! Leave our medications and health care alone!!!!!

column9: I am on 10/325 4X day for breakthrough pain, with 60 mg Morphine xr, Am and Pm for main pain management. As for the 10/325, it works GREAT for fast pain relief. Especially when I can be off my feet.(which is very seldom running a restaurant) But is SHORT in duration. Also on Zonegran 100 mg 3x day and Neurontin 300 mg 3x day to help with the nerve pain associated with a venous stasis ulcer on my lower left leg. column2: tomsdiy, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Suffered bad car accident 36 years ago; chronic pain ever since. Last 2 years have had severe lower back pain and sharp pains in right leg. Nerve tests and MRIs reveal a pinched nerve in L4-L5. Am being referred to spine specialist in Minneapolis, MN. Have been on generic Percocet for 10 months. Takes care of most of the pain. Does not make me hallucinate as other pain meds. Am well aware of addictive nature. But have safeguards in place: Rx must be renewed monthly by doctor. Living in small town pharmacist knows me personally, so I can not "pull anything." Also, having a caring RN as a wife is an automatic safeguard. Plus, personally, it's often a "balancing act" between, "How much pain can I tolerate" vs "How concerned am I about becoming addicted?" Pain management is a "package deal" of medication, injections, surgery, physical therapy, lifestyle changes, etc., as shown in so many articles on this WebMD chronic pain  newsletter, for which I am grateful. You do what you have to do to enjoy at least some quality of life.

column2: Thankful Patient, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Percocet is a miracle. I am fairly heavy, and most medications I have taken either have a reduced effect, or no effect on me at all. This does not hold true for Percocet. I've been given percocet in the past and know the dangers of using it, and have found that this knowledge makes it easier to USE and not ABUSE. As good as it is, this drug is very dangerous and can easily kill an abusive pill popper. So, with that aside, I would like to spread the good word about percocet and give thanks to the creators of this wonderful modern miracle.I have severe lower back pain, it's something my doctors haven't been able to find an etiology for, and had become a problem for me concerning sleep. I would go approximately a week without sleeping before it became too much and I would shut down. My Doctor found this highly worrisome and decided I should be given Percocet after having tried many other drugs with little to no effect. Percocet did the trick, and the best part was I only had to take it for one month before I decided I could move onto a lighter and less dangerous medication. It took away all pain I was experiencing, and it left me able to resume work.Secondly, and most recently, I've had a corrective surgery completed on my right foot. A double tendon transfer and a calcaneal osteotomy. The doctors warned me that the pain would be nearly unbearable and that I would not be able to work for at least two weeks. This wasn't true due to Percocet being available. I was prescribed a stronger dose than before, 10/325, and found myself able to continue with work less than two days after the surgery. Granted I do feel a bit light-headed, and occasionally I feel nauseated, but thanks to Percocet, I can continue living my life the way I want to.

column2: mom of three girls, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had lumbar surgery and with the percocet medicine, i am able to take care of my young children without complications of pain.I been taking it for 1 and 1/2 years. I noticed how well it helped when my surgeon just completely cut me off it.  When that happened i was in chronic pain once again. I couldn't bend,walk,reach,or interact with my kids activities without being in pain. I've tried vicodin and it does not take the pain away, i missed out on social events at my kids school because the pain that returned was too much for me to bear.  Physical therapy only helped for the ten minutes while hooked to the electric shockers. Once i walked out my pain returned within 15 to 20 minutes. I wish that some of these doctors could get the same surgery to understand how important a pain killer works for an indivisual. They may be smart but unless one goes through surgery then one does not know the importance of what works for a patient. Now i go to a pain clinic and they give me an injection, but that also only relives the pain for a few hours. I hope that anyone who gets surgery can find the help with what works for them. I pray everyday that no one has to endure back pain or any pain that is chronic,constant, and severe.  I will not be able to give my children 100% physical support to teach them sports dance or any phsyical activity.

column2: Rblue, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking percocet 10/325 for about a year. I'm 61 and have hypothyroid disease too that is being treated with synthroid.  My dosage of percocet is three times daily.  Occasionally I have to go for a fourth pill because of my severe neuopathic pain.  Until I started the percocet I didn't have a life.  I know I probably need to stop because of all the medical community's hate for the drug but it has allowed me to do the things I want to do without pain.  I have problems with anxiety so psychaitrists won't prescribe anything to help me there because I'm using percocet.  It's like I'm unclean or something.  I am in a CBT group that's helping, I think, my anxiety.  I know there are concerns with percocet because it is a narcotic but used with discretion it can actually give a decent life back to a person.  I don't understand why drs are so reluctant to help with anything else once they learn you are taking percocet.  It's very sad.

column9: I am only 18 and I have been on percocet 7.5/325 for four years now. I have had three back surgeries and am always in constant pain. I am VERY "dependent" on this medication. I am taking it as prescribed and only when I really need it, however that didnt prevent me from building a tollerance either. You need more and more. column9: be careful when you start this pain killer, because it will start working even if you take a very small amount like half a pill. The effectiveness starts with you. start with small amounts every 4 hours don't go over this. If you wake up with pain eat then take 2 tylenol wait 4 hours take as little as possible, tell your doctor your fear of addiction. The whole idea is to get rid of the pain before you forget how it feels to be pain free. Don't be afraid you can beat anything unnatural, you are stroger than you think. the whole idea is to have the pain killer when you need it without the doctors treating you like a out of control person when your not. Don't beat yourself up try to get well and don't feel guilty because the medicine makes you feel good and remember that you can feel good without it.

column2: Kay78, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This is to respond to aries555. I have been on this med for 3yrs for back surgery that resulted in me living with chronic pain for the rest of my life. Yes, this med will give you pain all over when you stop it after being on it for such a long time. It can cause you to have severe stomach cramps, diarrhea, sweats, and make your pain that you are being treated for even worse if the medication is suddenly stopped. This does not mean that you were addicted, it simply means that you were depended on the drug to relieve your pain. It's either take the medication or suffer. I'm taking the meds. Most people don't like being depended on the med, but it's better than being miserable and bed ridden. One important thing to remember is to never allow yourself to run out of the medicine. It's when you run out, that you have these awful withdrawal effects. Also, if you plan on stopping this med, make sure you tell your Doctor so they can give you something to curb these withdrawal effects, or you can simply taper down on your own. By that I mean, instead of taking 5 a day, go to 4, then the next week try 3, then try breaking them in half until your body is comfortable enough without the medication. I hope this helps.

column9: I am hoping someone will read this and benefit from the unexpected results I recieved taking this medication.  I was prescribed Percocet/Oxycodone for pain following gallbladder surgery.  I found, however, that not only did it relieve the pain from surgery, if I took a dose immediately at the onset of an attack of Irritable Bowel Syndrome I could avoid it all together.  One dose or even at times only half a dose and I would avoid pain, bloating and severe diarrhea.  If you suffer from moderate to severe IBS as I do, discuss it with your doctor, see if perhaps it can work for you.  The only side effect I noticed was feeling a bit warm.  I am hot natured and noticed it but someone else may not have the same experience.

cat12121262, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: i have fibro "chronic pain" i have used this over 5 yrs. this med is as any other med. it effects all differently. u can become addicted to anything in the wrong situation. it has given me some pain free moments, otherwise i live at a pain level of 8 daily. one has to find the answer 4 yourself. it does not work for all just like dymatap makes some kids bounce off the wall, while others go nite nite. mis use of any med is horrible. do your research, become a team w/your docs. and "you" need to own your own illness. being irresponsible can come  w/any med. be it "over the counter" or script form. remember anything can be misused. what works for one may not work for the other. don't blame the med. one has to blame the user. own it and answer for it. put some work researching your own health. pain management is just that!! this medication has worked for me...because i choose to use it correctly. yes one does  have to rise up a notch or so when there is long term use...that comes w/the illness. if i had to stop taking this medication i am sure i would go thru withdrawel as w/anything. but for me it works to help "me" manage my pain. i couldnot even imagine not having this med in my life, the quality would just crash. it is not a wonder drug, but it allows me to have somewhat  of a lower pain level of life. i know it will never erase the pain, but w/other meds in combination helps to control the other ailments that come along w/this illness. open a book, get online,ask a ton of questions. find out what works for (you). as for me i am in a good place because i use as directed. if this is what helps me to be part of the "living" then great. i can't do everything i used to do being so active. but at least i am here for someone else that needs to read something like this to feel ok for taking this medication. for me to let them know if it works for u....don't let anyone make u feel weak for taking it. read, search,question and for god's sake try to grab some moments of LIFE!

column9: This drug is amazing in every way. People who whine about withdrawal symptoms try prednisone and see how much WORSE those side effects are. This drug makes me feel amazing it helps with my anxiety, depression, and my pain! It helps me focus and keeps me driven to succeed! I work harder, I smile more, more talkative and friendlier, and I feel like I can handle anything thrown my way. I TAKE IT AS PRESCRIBED that is the most important part. Misuse causes serious problems don't be a dumbass and take more then prescribed simple solution. MAY NOT WORK FOR EVERYONE, but sadly you are in the minority, because this truly is a miracle drug for chronic pain. I am on constant pain level of 8 and it relieves to about a 2 sometimes it disappears all together. Doctors are evil they would rather see you suffer then to help you, just to PROTECT THEIR OWN BUTT! column9: I had always had chronic back pain. Shawnee, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was started on percocet while in the hospital for 3 days (just tyhis past weekend) recovering from an abdominal hysterectomy. The 1st day all I did was vomit every couple hours (this may have also been from the anesthesia-not really sure) The 2nd and 3rd day I couldn't stay awake. (again, this may have been due to the toll the surgery took on my body-or it could have been the medicine, I wish I knew which one it was) when I went home on the 4th day, I didn't have my script filled yet so didn't have any that day. On the 5th and 6th day after getting my script filled, It had the totally opposite effects on me - I have been wide awake and very wired and not able to sleep at all. Today is the 7th day, I did not take any at all today, it is a little after midnight, my body feels weary and tired - yet my mind is still totally awake and I cannot seem to fall asleep. Even after only about 6 hours of total sleep over the past three days. Percocet and ibuprofin are the only meds I am taking for my post-surgery pain so I don't know what else could be causing all of this. It does help to releive some of pain when I take it and it did make my mood pretty upbeat - but, if not being able to get any proper rest is a regular side effect, I don't know if its worth it. So far, after reading about 15 reviews, I have only read one other review where someone else also reported that it made them wired.

column2: Lexi, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had lower back pain since a car accident 5/06; I was rear-ended by a man who claimed to be going 55 mph (I was sitting still to make a left turn - waiting on traffic).  I recently had surgery for a L4-L5 fusion w/trinity allograft and am still in a lot of pain.  I have been on Oramorph 15mg 3/xs a day and Percocet 10/325mg for breakthrough pain and it has recently stopped being effective.  My doctor has decided to put me on Oxycontin 2x/day with Percocet 10/325mg 4x/day when it is time for a refill on my meds which is within the next few days.  I have read the reviews on Oxycontin and I am scared too death to start taking it but I have GOT to have some relief!  The morphine + percocet combo is not working any longer.  I can sympathize and empathize with any and all people who suffer from chronic pain.  It affects every aspect of your life.  I hope that I do not have any adverse effects from Oxycontin + Percocet when I start it this month ... God bless you all!

column2: (Caregiver)
column9: My father is 82 years old, and he is recovering from his second replacement knee surgery.  For his pain, the doctor has prescribed Percocet.  My father is not experiencing any pain while on this medication, but he has become confused, disoriented, dry mouth, not sleeping, and constipated while on this drug.  These side effects concerns us, especially the confusion, and disorientation, because of his age.  The doctor said it is common for patients to experience side effects while on Percocet, and that each patient could experience different types.  The doctor also said the confusion and disorientation  my father is having is a common experiencing a patient may have from this medication. My father is not experiencing any pain from the knee surgery while on this medication, but because of his age, I am fearing that there may be other complications the side effects from Percocet could triger.  My father made a decision to have replacement knee surgery on his left knee, because the knee was giving him problems.  He prepared himself for the surgery and rehabilitation process that was to be expected.  He had his right knee replace about a year ago, and the total experience was a good one; from the surgery to the rehabilitation.  He did not experience the side effects from the pain medication after his first knee replacement surgery as he is experiencing this second time around.  The pain medication prescribe for him, back then, work well with very little side effects.  At this time, I do not know what type of pain medication he was on when he had his first knee replacement sergury, but I am going to find out.  I am wondering, could the confusion, and the disorientation from Percocet cause other complications for my father, who again is 82 years old?

column2: ZNickey, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I use Oxycodone/APAP for 2 different chronic conditions and have had excellent luck with it for treating moderate-severe pain.  I do not use it on a daily basis but only when one of the conditions flare which has resulted in me using 3-10 pills a week and I have had no problem with addiction nor have I had to increase the dosage.  I personally have not had this issue, but a major problem encountered by many people initially taking Percocet is nausea; you can take this medication in combination with Benadryl and it will decrease the upset stomach and increase the medication's effectiveness in pain relief as you are combining a opioid with an antihistamine.  It will also increase drowsiness but people taking this medication on a short term basis should not be driving anyway.  With all of that said, no 2 people are alike as you can see how these reviews differ so my best advice is try it and if the medication is not for you, contact your doctor as there are TONS of options out their for pain relief.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been taking percocet 5-325 for 10 days now. Dosage was for 1 pill every 4 hrs. I was up to 2 tablets every 3 hrs when I called Dr to let her know it was cutting the pain. She told me to take 2 tablets and added gabapentin 300 mg 3 times a day.  I've taken about 110 percocet pills in 10 days now without any major effects. Cuts the pain from ruptured disc ok although I know the pain is still there. I'm not noticing any major effects except slight light headedness if I turn my head too quick. I don't want to be on the pills too long but they are cutting the pain somewhat. Like others have mentioned, don't let the pain get to be too great. I try to cut back to 1 tablet during the day when I'm feeling better in an attempt to not take too much.  Vicodin did not work at all in cutting the pain though.  In addition, I have had alcohol for two events during treatment and I haven't noticed any issues with increased effects with alcohol. column9: given for after i had 3 wisdom teeth removed in surgery. i am a 28 yr old skinny, healthy, female, only 1 lower wisdom tooth was slightly impacted. i couldn't do novocane b/c my dentist has discovered i require double the dosage to work on me. i used percocet(have never used it before b/c vicodin makes me vomit profusely. i have dislocated my shoulder over 20 times, but still haven't used many prescribed pain pills except vicodine/codeine a handful of times. but on this, i have not slept in 30+ hours, am feeling paranoid, foggy, yet still in pain. it both sharpens and numbs different aspects of my jaw pain. i have trouble breathing, my throat is sore. i am on the 3rd day of recovery and only took 2 pills in the last 24-30 hours (i take them a half pill at a time; The pills are 5mg of oxycodone.) but just now i took a whole one b/c i am DESPERATE to sleep and am out of sleeping pills. my mouth is very very dry. the first day it worked pretty well, although i was still in a lot of pain. the second day i was in way more pain, and took more. always at 1/2 a pill increments. i had taken 9 by the end of the second day and my insomnia was horrible, but i just thought it was the pain. by the third day though,i spaced. suddenly, i looked down at the clock and it was 7am THE NEXT DAY. i hadn't slept, but was in a fog, trying to get comfortable, fiddling with knitting, on the computer, reading. icing. drinking water, keeping stil. trying to numb out. starting the second day but hitting the third, it made me feel like i was on an amphetimine instead of relaxing me. need to call the oral surgeon tomorrow b/c i'm having a very bad mental reaction. wierd.

column2: painpro, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: im a 26 yr old male with spondylolisthesis, lumbar disc bulging at 2 levels and arthritic formation at 2 levels and im rapidly declining. ive been on vicodin, ultram, robaxin, skelaxin, celebrex and now ive graduated to percocet twice a day. takes the edge off, thats about it. works the best so far though. it causes constipation, but not as bad as vicodin for some reason (percocet is only a stronger version). hard to get doc to write for this drug, but most docs dont understand how life changing constant pain is. side effects can be strong, but they are worth it. take this drug on an empty stomach as it will have the most relief, the more you eat with it the less effect it will have in relieving your pain. when you get to the point that you need percocet i can probably speak for most sufferers when i say who cares about addiction, its better than literally going crazy being unable to walk or even do your own laundry. wish docs understood that most people feel like schmucks going in asking for percocet, so if someone asks for it, they need to consider the amount of pain they are in instead of making you feel like an addict looking for your next score. good luck to anyone reading this and is experiencing the same amount of pain ive been in and will likely be in the rest of my life.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Percocet for post-op pain following each one of my cesarean sections.  It was easy to use, very effective in pain reduction, and had few side effects for me.  I am sensitive to codeine (it makes me vomit), but had no nausea with Percocet. I am currently on a five-day prescription of Lortab for pain following oral surgery, and the Lortab is giving me severe nausea, although these two drugs are quite similar. I was groggy at the prescribed dosage of Percocet but cut th dose in half after the first day post-op and had very good results.  I stopped using it as soon as I could manage it, because I understand that this drug can become addictive.  It was just right for my situation.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Percocet on-and-off for nearly a year due to a DVT, neuropathy, post-surgery, and for pain due to prolonged swelling in my thigh and knee. I take it as opposed to Vicodin because I noticed a tendency to build up fluids with that drug, even when taken for short periods (with existing problems with swelling, this is obviously not helpful). Also as opposed to high-dose Ibuprophen due to stomach issues and ineffctiveness to my pain. Percocet has been extremely effective with all of my pain and I have noticed no side effects at all, including no withdrawal if I miss even several doses (my current dosage is 5-10mg every 4 hours or as needed, largely based on my level of activity and subsequent swelling). I even stopped usage for a period of about a week because the swelling and pain subsided, with no adverse effects. However, I am aware that this is a rare circumstance and should not be expected. This drug is extremely effective and that in itself makes it habit forming, as I noticed that even though it was not needed for pain, I fought the urge to take it. This being the case with many such drugs, I highly recommend Percocet because of its effectiveness.

column2: kim3884, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Percocet for about 5 years now for sever Rhuematiod Arthritis. The drug works wonders! However, in reading comments from others, I will agree that your dose needs to be adjusted because your body becomes use to it. However, I've been given Oxycodone to take along with it and I haven't had to have an adjustment to my pain medications in over 1 1/2 years now. And yes, I've been given other pain meds in the past (even stronger drugs like morphine), but this drug has worked the best for me. Without this drug I would not have any quality of life and would probably be bed ridden and on disability. Because of this drug, I am able to work, although I do have a desk job.   I can also enjoy other activities that others take for granite.  I can go to out to lunch or dinner, or go to the grocery store or the mall for short periods of time (not more than 45 minutes to an hour because of the pain), so it's improved my quality of life.I do realize that this drug is very additive and is abused, but for patients who really do need this drug it is a life-saver. The only bad thing I can say about this drug is the withdraw from it. I had forgotten to take it with me once when I went out of town for a weekend and will never do that again. I had to go to an emergency room to get a an RX to tide me over until I got home.

column2: beeprepared2@cox.net, 65-74 Male  (Patient)

column9: I took percs for a broken foot from a car wreck I was in. They work great. my nose was very itchy, but other than that, they were great. One thing people need to be aware of is that this drug, when taken for an extended amount of time, inhibits the brains ability to fight pain. In other words, the more you take this medicine, the more you need it. Since percocet is an opioid (i.e. it is in the same class as herioine) after long periods of use your brain stops producing dopamine because you are supplying it through the percs and it is "tricked" into thinking you don't need it anymore. confusing? I know! bottom line: only take percs for a short period of time. I don't suggest it for chronic pain. I am sympathetic for those living with chronic pain. keep being strong!!

column2: justme, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: After taking 5mg Percocet for over a year, my doc changed me over to 10/325mg Percocet. I find it to be very effective as far as pain relief in my back, but have noticed a rather bad headache when it starts to wear off. Use this medication with caution, as the longer you take it, the more tolerant you become, and the more you must take. Take it no longer than you must, and wean yourself off of it as the withdrawals can be rather unpleasant if you suddenly stop taking it, and may include nausea, vomiting, headache, insomnia, and a few other things as well. Hope this helps.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Percocet 5/325 mg. twice daily for almost 6 months due to a severe fall that completely shattered my tailbone. Although very effective for the first 3 or 4 months I now find that the pain relief is short lived. I have spoken to my doctor about this and it is very common for the medication to have a decreased pain relieving effect after months of use. The next option is to switch the 5 mg. to 10 mg. My concern is this: when the 10 mg. starts to decrease in effect, what is next? I have resigned myself to the fact that I will need to take some sort of prescribed pain reliever for an indefinite amount of time although surgery is an option, there are no guarantees and I have been told I could end up worse off than I am now and that worries me GREATLY. It is unimaginable to me what I would be like without this medication, I still have a very difficult time with everyday activities, but the medication does help (even though it is a limited amount of help). People that do not live with pain on a daily basis cannot understand how it affects EVERYTHING you do, it is consuming. You have to make so many concessions due to your pain. It takes on a life of it's own while complicating yours. I just remind myself that I am doing all that I can to keep it under control and not letting it take control of me, which is a very difficult thing to do. Do your best to take care of yourself, take it easy and realize you now have limitations, but DO NOT let the pain take over your life--easier said than done, but not an impossibility. As corny as it may sound, positive thoughts really do help to make a difference!!!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
susieq64, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have mod-severe fibromyalgia and have had it all my life. My doctor back home in MN prescribed 7.5/500 mg which is a moderate dose and I never had a problem with it. When you have this condition, it's all you can do to get thru the day and try to live a normal (as possible) life. Once I moved to KS, my doctor followed my previous doctors treatment plan for a short time and then decided I was taking too much and reduced my dose by 50%. Needless to say, there are days that I can't get out of bed and yes, there has been times when I've taken more than prescribed and followed the old dosage to get by. I might have to go on complete disability because it's very hard for me to work anymore. I've tried the "fm" med Lyrica and it's done nothing for me. I wish doctors would not automatically assume you're addicted if you take narcotics longer than a month. Unfortunetly, sometimes they are physically needed.

column9: Please be very careful using this medication. It is very addictive. I was on it for about 3 years on and off for kidney surgeries and female surgeries (yes, several surgeries in a very short time period)... I did not want to stop taking it. I knew I needed help getting off and talked to my doctor who helped me with antidepressants and sleeping pills. When I was on percocet, I felt high and I loved it, but it is not a way to live. Please find something else to use if you have pain for more than a month. I used so much that I built up a huge tolerance, meaning I had to take more and more the next dose to get the same relief. I was 130 pounds and was taking 30 to 40 mg at a time. Please be careful.

Overall though it did not make me nauseus, an was effective.  Thank goodness i had it or I would not have made it through without another Emergency Room trip for IV pain meds.

column2: bartender, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: it helps me walk better and control my pain better

column2: scary, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm using it for a recent broken bone and it seems to help.  However, if I don't take it when scheduled the pain comes back and then it's hard to get control over it.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was taking this after oral (dental) surgery.  Twenty times 325mg every three hours over three days.  One of the less serious side effects is supposed to be constipation.  It caused constipation alright - totally shut down my elimination system.  I was drinking plenty of liquids, nevertheless my waste turned into brick.  I was only able to eliminate two days after I stopped taking the medicine.  I'm fifty years old and have never been constipated like this, ever.  The feeling is horrible, incredibly painful to boot. Something to keep in mind when taking this stuff.  Personally, I'll never take Percocet again. As far as percocet's pain relieving properties go, my dosage was only effective at relieving pain, from ca 70 minutes into taking the drug, for a one hour of the three hour period it was supposed to be for.  Nevertheless it helped somewhat.  Sometimes it made me woozy, at other times I could barely tell I had taken anything at all.  Of course, that may all be dosage related.

column2: Speakuppeople, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: PERCOCET has been given a bad "rap" because of people abusing drugs. People can abuse anything. This is the ONE MEDICATION that works for my pain and with NO SIDE EFFECTS!  ARE YOU LISTENING, DOCTORS/Prescribers? The Department if Justice regulates Percocet, Vicodin, Lorecet and all the other narcotics and scheduling.  PEOPLE, we need to write them! Doctors are afraid to prescribe the medications that work fear of law suits, so they are all trying to prescribe the latest antidepressants out there, like CYBALTA, EFFEXOR, LRICA, etc. I am sure that these may work for some and great for depression and in some cases pain, BUT THEY CAN ALSO BE ADDICTING!  I am happy for those of you who can take them. I cannot. I have a friend who cannot get off of PAXIL! We have to speak, people and watch out for ourselves. The FDA has not done too well lately,and we have to watch out for ourselves and communicate with our doctors. There are laws for us, also and if we have a disease and are in pain, we have to be taken care of and not allowed to suffer as human beings.  So many of the antidepressants, not only have severe side effects (like nausea, dizzyness, headache, chest pains)etc., but damage to the liver and kidneys. Percocet does have acetaminopen in it, but if you do not take over 4,000 mg a day, then you should be okay.  The stigma placed on narcotics should not be there, especially when a physician prescibes this for their patient who is in PAIN! I would not be able to WALK or function without Percocet. I am not addicted, but IF I ever was addicted to anything, I would rather it be to this and able to lead a normal life, than an antidepressant or something else extremely detrimental to the essential organs in my body and may not live as long. Most of the medications just cover up the symptoms anyway unless it is an anti-iflammatory; those you have to be careful with, also. Good luck to us all in this horrible realm of pain.  God Bless. Try and have a positive attitude!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had to use this medication for several different problems (kidney stones, endometriosis, and lower back pain). This has been one of the only pain medications that has helped me through all my medical problems. I agree that there is a stigma with it and I can't stand that! It is so restricted to the people who actually need it because of the drug abusers out there and that is absoultely terrible. Hopefully soon I will be able to live without it, but it has definitely helped me and I would recommend it to others in pain.

column2: MARY, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I HAVE SEVERE CHRONIC PAIN AND COULD NOT FUNCTION WITHOUT PERCOCET. I WOULD ONLY BE SURVIVING AND NOT ACTUALLY HAVE A LIFE. THANK YOU, PERCOCET. I HAVE "FIBROMYALGIA," A STRANGE SYNDROME; BUT THE EXTREME ALL OVER BODY PAIN IS HARD TO DESCRIBE. YOUR MUSCLES, TENDONS, NERVES, BONES AND YOUR ENTIRE BODY DOES NOT FUNCTION AND SOME DAYS YOU CANNOT GET OUT OF BED. FIBROMYALGIA IS DIFFICULT TO DIAGNOSE AND THERE IS A LOT OF ANXIETY THAT COMES ALONG WITH THAT.  ONCE IT IS DIAGNOSED, DOCTORS SEEM TO WANT TO USE YOU AS A GUINEA PIG AND TRY ALL THE NEW DRUGS, EVEN THOUGH WITH FIBROMYALGIA, COMES A HIGH SENSITIVITY TO MOST MEDICATIONS!  ALSO, WITH FIBROMYALGIA, PATIENTS HAVE A LOWER TOLERANCE FOR PAIN. NOTHING MUCH HELPS.  THE ONLY THING THAT HAS HELPED ME WITHOUT ANY SIDE EFFECTS IS PERCOCET. I DO NOT FIND IT ANYMORE "ADDICTING" THAN ANY OF THE OTHER MEDICATIONS.  IF YOU HAVE PAIN, YOU ARE GOING TO TAKE SOMETHING. EVEN NSAIDS ARE ADDICTING IF YOU TAKE THEM EVERY DAY FOR PAIN AND SO IS ALCOHOL IF YOU DRINK IT DAILY TO CALM YOURSELF OR WHATEVER. HOW MANY DOCTORS DRINK ALCOHOL?  HOW MANY DOCTORS HAVE REALLY EXPERIENCED SEVERE CHRONIC PAIN?  I BET YOU THAT THEY WOULD TAKE THE PERCOCET! I DO NOT SPEAK FOR ALL DOCTORS AND DO UNDERSTAND THAT THEY ARE SCARED TO PRESCRIBE PERCOCET BECAUSE OF THE SCRUTINY PLACED ON THEM, BUT LEGITIMATE PATIENTS IN PAIN AND IN ORDER TO LEAD A SOMEWHAT NORMAL LIFE, NEED THIS DRUG.IT MAY NOT HELP SOME PEOPLE BUT IT HAS HELPED ME FOR THREE YEARS. I WOULD BE IN A WHEEL CHAIR WITHOUT IT. I AM DISABLED WITHOUT IT AND THE PAIN IS SO EXCRUCIATING, THAT IF IT WAS TAKEN AWAY, I DO NOT THINK I COULD LIVE. MORE PEOPLE NEED TO WRITE TO THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE TO HAVE PERCOCET AS A SCHEDULE III DRUG SO DOCTORS ARE NOT AFRAID TO PRESCRIBE IT.  IT IS NOW LISTED ON THE WEB SITE AS SCHEDULE II AND I DISAGREE WITH IT. ALSO, IT IS SO HUMILIATING IF SOMEONE KNOWS YOU ARE ON PERCOCET BECAUSE OF THE BOGUS STIGMA PLACED ON IT. THIS NEEDS TO GO AWAY. WE ARE NOT DRUGGIES!

column2: Ann, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Percocet goes straight to my pain and I have sever chronic pain! It does not make me dizzy or nauseated. I HAVE NO side effects and do not feel I need to take more than needed. One would know if you take too much because you would get dizzy or euphoric.  Any pain medication that you feel any euphoria, in my opinion, has addictive properties.  When Percocet 5/325 or a 10/325 cut in half, relieves my pain, I am not dizzy OR SLEEPY and can drive the car and do any activity. I am not tired like some medications make you. I am not depressed like some other meds make you. I do not know what I would do without this medication because I have a high sensitivity to most medications of any kind, especially NSAIDS and anti-depressants, which doctors sometimes use for pain.  It is ashame that Percocet has been abused by many, therefore making it a SCHEDULE II drug.  Doctors seem to have a fear of prescribing it and this is a drug which works for me.  Doctors should not be afraid to prescribe this medication, especially to an older person and the doctor knows they are in pain.  There has to be TRUST going in all directions.  Patients need to stop being law suit happy and realize that doctors would help more if their hands were not tied because of the fear of being sued by prescribing SCHEDULE II drugs.  EVERYTHING can be potentially addictive! I cannot take AMBIEN that is a schedule V, nor ROZAREM (compare to melatonin in the body). Talk about being addictive and take AMBIEN! I also had chest pains and other side effects from it. Stay away from AMBIEN; you can't get off of it! Alcohol is addicting, chocolate is addicting, too much eating is addicting, soda is addicting.  We need to write the Department of Justice under DEA and have Percocet lowered to a Schedule III drug, such as Vicodin, Lortab and Lorcet.  I cannot take those meds!  I have many side effects from them, but not one from Percocet. Percocet is a good med and should not be kept from those of us who need it to live!

column2: Mrose, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was taken off of this and put on tramadol. That drug did not work and caused severe nausea and vomiting every time I tried to take it. Percocet worked for my severe pain with very few side affects. If you only take it when the pain is severe I found it had less of a "buzzy" type effect which I'd rather avoid. Yes, you do have to be careful as I noticed needing to increase the dosage faster than I would have liked but, honestly if you really only take it when you absolutely have to then you can avoid most of that. My second time on it, I followed that criteria and never had to increase the dose once.I wish doctors would learn more about pain management. Most Gp's will put you on ANYTHING BUT a narcotic when some types of pain will NOT respond to other drugs well. Meanwhile those of us with severe pain have no life at all till we can get on something that actually works!I have to think if it was the doctor in that kind of pain he'd not hesitate to take what works and would get it a lot sooner than most of us do.

column2: navysea7, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: My only concern with this combination pain medication goes along with many other combination pain medications which have added high doses of either aspirin or acetemetophine to their primary pain reliever such as oxycodone in the percocet.  I just don't thing that physicians think sometimes before they write a prescription for chronic pain that for the most part patients don't need or want all that extra aspirin or acetemetophine; especially, for someone like myself who has been taking Percocet for pain for the past twenty years for Bi lateral avascular neucrosis.  However, I have been able to get this point across to my new physician and he just writes for 5mg of oxycodone w/o the added APAP.
